channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: C, C++, and Perl Software Engineers, Let’s Keep the Internet Safe. UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: A leading digital safeguarding solutions provider is looking for a software engineer experienced in C, C++, or Perl. You’ll have strong Linux knowledge and a methodical approach to problem solving that you use to investigate, replicate, and address customer issues. Your keen understanding of firewalls, proxies, Iptables, Squid, VPNs/IPSec and HTTP(S) will be key to your success at this company.

item.title: Senior Perl Developer with Cross-Trained Chops. UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: Adventure Awaits! Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Clever folks know that if you’re lucky, you can earn a living and have an adventure at the same time. Enter our international client: online trading is their game, and they're looking for Perl folks with passion, drive, and an appreciation for new experiences.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report.

item.title: Jumping Groups
item.description: Little more detailed analysis than regular. Still very concise, good job.

item.title: Rearrange by Jumps
item.description: Lucky week, we got Perl and Rust solutions getting discussed in the blog post. Nice one, keep it up.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #212
item.description: Nicely re-worded description made it so easy to follow. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Lead to Gold and 1 2 3
item.description: Nice and easy to understand solution without any gimmicks. Well done.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 212
item.description: Another week another cool Perl one-liner. Keep it up.

item.title: Jumping words and batching arrays
item.description: Raku magic made the task so easy. Still getting it together is an art. Thank you for the contributions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 212
item.description: I loved the way Raku magic is implemented in Perl. Very impressive. Well done.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 212
item.description: Great show of Perl power. I just loved it. Thank you for sharing knowledge with us.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 212
item.description: Lots of Raku magic and interesting story about the second task. Keep us entertained every week.

item.title: PWC212 - Rearrange Groups
item.description: Perl got preference this week. Nice one. Thanks for your contributions.

item.title: PWC212 - Jumping Letters
item.description: Nice explanation of each and every tiny details. Nothing is left for the readers. Spoon feeding.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #212
item.description: Nice and easy solution with plenty of explanation. Good job, well done.

item.title: Letters and Groups
item.description: Nice use of multi keyword of Raku. Nice detailed discussion as always. Keep it up great work.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 212
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Jumping Letters" and "Rearrange Groups" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 213
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Fun Sort" and "Shortest Route". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Thinking on a data collection API
Data::Table - Weekly Travelling in CPAN
item.description: CPAN travellers having fun every week, thanks to Cheok-Yin Fung.

item.title: The CfP has just been extenden:
item.description: The Perl and Koha Conference 2023 is now accepting talks. Please do submit.

item.title: #612 - Coming Soon!
item.description:
Hi there,

So what's coming soon!

Well it's the subject of the talk to be presented by Curtis Poe at The Perl and Raku Conference 2023, TORONTO, Canada. I have been waiting for the event to come to Canada as going to America was never on card. Post 9/11, travelling to America having Mohammad as first name isn't good idea. Having seen the list of speakers, I am sure it's going to be lots of fun. I really wanted to attend the event and meet the top guns. So what's stopping me? I haven't been keeping well in the recent months. I know my current employer, Oleeo has been regular sponsor of London Perl Workshop and have sponsored selected few to attend various events in the past. Having said, I have to be mentally prepared before I take the plunge but I really don't want to miss the opportunity. I still remember the first time, I attended the talk by Curtis was at German Perl Workshop 2018 and it was about Rescuing Legacy Code. After that I met him again at The Perl Conference 2019, Riga. I think that was the last time I ever attended any conference in person. I am not sure if I still have time to reserve a place or even submit a short talk proposal at The Perl and Raku Conference 2023.

Talking about conference, I would also like to mention another big event in Europe, The Perl and Koha Conference in Helsinki. They have extended time to accept talks. So if you are planning to attend then please do submit your proposal now. I am planning to visit India in the month of August otherwise I would have given a push.

I am a big fan of writing skills of brian d foy, Curtis Poe, Damian Conway, Dave Cross and many more. It's not just about blog post but also about their books. Dave Cross recently published GitHub Actions Essentials. I haven't read it yet but I am confident it is going to be worth spending time and money.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter and please do take extra care of your health.
item.dc:subject: editorial
